snippet.textDisplay: I haven't play the SNES version (didn't have one at the time); I played the 'remaster' PSP version; Dracula was actually easier for me, but then, It's hard to compare the difficulty I face as a child and the one I'm facing now as a grown up :P (also: it took me quite a while to find the trick for the NES version, once discovered, it was a lot easier -- I didn't find any particular trick on Dracula X other than learning his attack patterns)
snippet.textOriginal: I haven't play the SNES version (didn't have one at the time); I played the 'remaster' PSP version; Dracula was actually easier for me, but then, It's hard to compare the difficulty I face as a child and the one I'm facing now as a grown up :P (also: it took me quite a while to find the trick for the NES version, once discovered, it was a lot easier -- I didn't find any particular trick on Dracula X other than learning his attack patterns)

Ok ok, seems easy enough *Dies by hunch back* ok ok they only got me once
Ok lets try this again, *dies by hunch back again* ...ok i got one more life left i can do this!
*gets past hunchbacks YOUR UR MOTHER!!!! ok lets keep goin... *gets killed by dragon head thing* *game over screen apears* SHIIT!!!!!

snippet.textDisplay: Alas, much as I love the first GBA game (Circle of the Moon), it is officially a "gaiden" game, a side-story which may or may not tie in with the "real" game universe. An example of the same concept, albeit as an anime OSV rather than a game, would be "Tenchi in Tokyo" as opposed to the original "Tenchi Muyo" series. KONAMI has confirmed, at the very least, that the Baldwins\Graves are in no way tied to the Belmont clan (the whip wielded is not Vampire Killer for one). Sorry to disappoint... :/
snippet.textOriginal: Alas, much as I love the first GBA game (Circle of the Moon), it is officially a "gaiden" game, a side-story which may or may not tie in with the "real" game universe. An example of the same concept, albeit as an anime OSV rather than a game, would be "Tenchi in Tokyo" as opposed to the original "Tenchi Muyo" series. KONAMI has confirmed, at the very least, that the Baldwins\Graves are in no way tied to the Belmont clan (the whip wielded is not Vampire Killer for one). Sorry to disappoint... :/

snippet.textDisplay:
I think the reason the Castlevania heroes have transitioned from barbaric to gothic can mainly be attributed to when the games were made; back in the 80's, buff action heroes were it. they were what was popular. however, as games came into their own and the art style of the games was more focused on, the characters became more fitting to their enviroment and game, and now we have the more gothic, noblemen characters in recent Castlevania games.

but, as always, SIMON FTW!!
snippet.textOriginal:
I think the reason the Castlevania heroes have transitioned from barbaric to gothic can mainly be attributed to when the games were made; back in the 80's, buff action heroes were it. they were what was popular. however, as games came into their own and the art style of the games was more focused on, the characters became more fitting to their enviroment and game, and now we have the more gothic, noblemen characters in recent Castlevania games.

but, as always, SIMON FTW!!

snippet.textDisplay: No, there are no guidelines for opinions, what I said is "there are guidelines to follow when choosing the best composed songs"
snippet.textOriginal: No, there are no guidelines for opinions, what I said is "there are guidelines to follow when choosing the best composed songs"

snippet.textDisplay:
Yes, that's true. But there are some guidelines to follow: melodic line, chord succession, arrangement, etc.. There a lot of more "complex" songs which use dominant's dominant chord, major tonic, key changes, etc..

This song is well arranged and sounds nice, but it's quite simple. Its chord succession Dm Bb Dm Bb -- C D C D -- Dm C Bb A - Dm C Bb A...
snippet.textOriginal:
Yes, that's true. But there are some guidelines to follow: melodic line, chord succession, arrangement, etc.. There a lot of more "complex" songs which use dominant's dominant chord, major tonic, key changes, etc..

This song is well arranged and sounds nice, but it's quite simple. Its chord succession Dm Bb Dm Bb -- C D C D -- Dm C Bb A - Dm C Bb A...

snippet.textDisplay:
It is NOT one of the best Castlevania songs. It's very good, I won't deny that, but there are more than 50 better songs from other Castlevania games.

I'm a really big fan of the saga. I have played every game, own every soundtrack and know the name of every single track of every game.
snippet.textOriginal:
It is NOT one of the best Castlevania songs. It's very good, I won't deny that, but there are more than 50 better songs from other Castlevania games.

I'm a really big fan of the saga. I have played every game, own every soundtrack and know the name of every single track of every game.
